title: The Little Match Girl
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in the bustling streets of a small Indian town, a little girl named Meera lived with her cruel stepmother. Meera's stepmother made her work hard every day, forcing her to sell matchsticks in the market
content:
Once upon a time, in the bustling streets of a small Indian town, a little girl named Meera lived with her cruel stepmother. Meera's stepmother made her work hard every day, forcing her to sell matchsticks in the market. Though Meera worked tirelessly, her stepmother never showed her any love or care.

One chilly winter evening, as the town celebrated the festival of lights, Deepavali, the streets were filled with glowing diyas and the sounds of laughter and crackers. Meera walked barefoot through the cold streets, carrying a small basket of matchsticks. Her thin, tattered saree did little to keep her warm. She shivered in the cold, calling out to the passersby, "Matchsticks for sale! Matchsticks for sale!" But no one stopped to buy her matches. Everyone was busy celebrating with their families.

Hungry and freezing, Meera wandered to the edge of the town, where she saw a large house filled with light and joy. She peeked through the window and saw a family gathered around a big table, enjoying a feast of sweets, samosas, and warm milk. Meera's stomach growled, and she wished she could be inside, sharing in the warmth and happiness.

Unable to bear the cold any longer, Meera sat down in a corner near the house and lit one of her matchsticks for a little warmth. As the flame flickered, she saw a beautiful vision. In the warm glow of the matchstick, she imagined herself sitting at a table, enjoying a plate full of delicious ladoos and warm halwa. But as the matchstick burned out, the vision faded, and she was once again cold and alone.

Desperate for more warmth, she lit another matchstick. This time, she imagined herself wearing a beautiful silk lehenga, with colorful bangles jingling on her wrists. She felt warm and happy as she twirled around, surrounded by bright diyas. But soon, the matchstick burned out, and the cold returned.

Google Ad 1

Meera lit another matchstick, and this time, she saw her late mother. Her mother’s face was kind and loving, and she reached out to Meera, saying, "Come to me, my child. You will never be cold or hungry again." Tears streamed down Meera’s face as she tried to hold onto the vision. She lit matchstick after matchstick, hoping to keep her mother close.

When the last matchstick burned out, Meera closed her eyes and smiled. She felt as though her mother was holding her hand and leading her to a warm, peaceful place.

The next morning, the townspeople found Meera sitting peacefully in the corner, her face lit with a soft smile. Though her body was still and cold, she seemed to have found the warmth and love she had longed for in life.

From that day on, the townspeople remembered Meera and her struggles. They vowed to care for the poor and lonely, ensuring no one would ever have to suffer the way she did.

Moral of the story: "Compassion and kindness can change lives." Always be mindful of those in need and offer help to those who are less fortunate.

title: The Pied Piper of Hamelin
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in the small Indian town of Nandipur, there was a terrible problem. The town was overrun by rats. They were everywhere—running through the streets, eating the grain, and even sneaking into people's homes
content:
Once upon a time, in the small Indian town of Nandipur, there was a terrible problem. The town was overrun by rats. They were everywhere—running through the streets, eating the grain, and even sneaking into people's homes. The townspeople tried everything they could think of to get rid of the rats, but nothing worked. They were desperate and didn't know what to do.

One day, a mysterious man arrived in the town. He was dressed in colorful clothes and carried a wooden flute. Introducing himself as Mohan, the flute player, he said to the townspeople, "I can rid your town of these rats. But it will cost you a hundred gold coins."

The townspeople agreed eagerly, promising to pay the man if he could truly rid the town of the rats.

Mohan took out his flute and began to play a strange, enchanting tune. As the music floated through the streets, the rats began to emerge from their hiding places. Mesmerized by the music, they followed Mohan as he walked through the town, playing his flute. He led the rats to the riverbank, where they all jumped into the water and drowned.

The townspeople were overjoyed and celebrated their victory. But when Mohan returned to claim his reward, the greedy town leaders refused to pay him the hundred gold coins. "Why should we give you so much gold for something as simple as playing a flute?" they sneered.

Google Ad 1

Mohan warned them, "You promised to pay me, and if you don’t, you will regret it."

The leaders laughed and dismissed him. Angry and betrayed, Mohan took out his flute and began to play another melody. This time, it was not the rats that followed him, but the children of the town. One by one, they came running out of their homes, enchanted by the music. Mohan led them out of Nandipur and into the nearby forest. When the music stopped, the children disappeared.

The townspeople were horrified and begged Mohan to bring their children back. They promised to pay him whatever he wanted. Mohan finally agreed but made them swear to always keep their promises. Only then did he play his flute again, leading the children back to the town.

From that day on, the people of Nandipur kept their word and learned the importance of honesty.

Moral of the story: "Always keep your promises and never cheat others." Breaking a promise can lead to dire consequences and loss of trust.

title: The Princess and the Pea
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in the vibrant kingdom of Rajapur, there lived a young prince named Veer. He was kind, noble, and wise, but he had one wish that had not been fulfilled—he longed to marry a true princess
content:
Once upon a time, in the vibrant kingdom of Rajapur, there lived a young prince named Veer. He was kind, noble, and wise, but he had one wish that had not been fulfilled—he longed to marry a true princess. The queen, his mother, was equally determined to find the perfect bride for her son, someone who was truly noble in heart and nature.

Many princesses from far-off lands came to the palace, claiming to be true royalty. However, the queen always suspected they were not genuine. She wanted her son to marry a princess who was not just born of royalty but who possessed true grace, sensitivity, and kindness.

One stormy night, as the rain poured down and lightning illuminated the skies, there was a knock at the palace gates. A young woman stood outside, drenched from head to toe. Her clothes were muddy and torn, and she looked weary from traveling. She said, “I am Princess Rani from a distant kingdom. I was caught in the storm and lost my way. May I take shelter here?”

The queen eyed her carefully and thought to herself, She says she is a princess, but how can I be sure?

The queen had an idea. She welcomed Princess Rani warmly and said, “Of course, my dear. You may stay here tonight.”

She ordered the servants to prepare a bed for the princess. But the queen, being clever, placed a single green pea under a stack of 20 soft cotton mattresses. She thought, If she is a true princess, her skin will be so delicate that she will feel the pea even under all the mattresses.

The next morning, the queen asked Princess Rani how she had slept.

The princess looked tired and said, “I hardly slept at all. Something hard was pressing into my back all night. I tossed and turned, and now I feel bruised.”

Hearing this, the queen smiled. Only a true princess could be so sensitive. She embraced Rani and said, “You are truly a princess, my dear! Only someone with the heart and sensitivity of royalty could have felt the pea.”

Prince Veer was overjoyed to meet someone so kind and delicate. He and Princess Rani were soon married in a grand celebration, and they lived happily ever after.

As for the pea, it was placed in the royal museum, where it became a symbol of true grace and sensitivity.

Moral of the story: "True nobility lies in one’s character, not just appearances." Sensitivity, kindness, and grace are qualities that define true royalty.

title: The Crow and the Fox
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a dense forest near the Indian village of Champapur, there lived a clever fox named Gopal and a proud crow named Kalu. Kalu, the crow, was known for his arrogance and often flaunted his finds to the other animals
content:
Once upon a time, in a dense forest near the Indian village of Champapur, there lived a clever fox named Gopal and a proud crow named Kalu. Kalu, the crow, was known for his arrogance and often flaunted his finds to the other animals.

One sunny morning, Kalu found a large, delicious piece of roti smeared with ghee near the village. Excited by his treasure, he quickly picked it up in his beak and flew to a tall tree in the forest to enjoy it in peace. As he perched on the tree, he noticed the other animals below eyeing him with envy. Kalu puffed out his chest with pride, feeling very important.

Now, Gopal, the fox, was passing by and saw the crow with the roti. Gopal’s stomach growled with hunger, and he decided to use his wit to get the roti for himself. Looking up at Kalu, he called out sweetly, "Oh, Kalu! What a magnificent bird you are! Your feathers are so shiny, and your eyes sparkle like gems!"

Kalu, flattered by the compliments, looked down at Gopal, his pride growing even more. But he held the roti firmly in his beak and said nothing.

Gopal continued, "Not only are you the most beautiful bird in the forest, but I’ve also heard that your voice is the sweetest. It is said that when Kalu the crow sings, the entire forest stops to listen. Will you please honor me with a song?"

Kalu, though proud, was also quite vain. The idea of everyone praising his voice was too tempting to resist. Forgetting the roti in his beak, he opened his mouth and let out a loud, “Caw! Caw! Caw!”

As soon as Kalu opened his beak, the roti fell to the ground. Quick as a flash, Gopal grabbed it and ran off, laughing. “Thank you for the delicious breakfast, Kalu!” he called over his shoulder.

Kalu sat on the branch, realizing he had been tricked. He felt embarrassed and muttered to himself, “I let my pride and vanity get the better of me.”

From that day on, Kalu learned to be wary of flattery and to not let his arrogance cloud his judgment.

Moral of the story: "Beware of flatterers, for they often have hidden motives." Stay humble, and don’t let vanity lead you into trouble.

title: The Little Red Hen
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a peaceful Indian village called Surajpur, there lived a hardworking little hen named Lal Pari. Lal Pari was kind and industrious, always busy tending to her small field and taking care of her chicks
content:
Once upon a time, in a peaceful Indian village called Surajpur, there lived a hardworking little hen named Lal Pari. Lal Pari was kind and industrious, always busy tending to her small field and taking care of her chicks. She lived with a lazy goat named Gopu, a laid-back cat named Sundari, and a sleepy buffalo named Bhola.

One bright morning, as Lal Pari was scratching the ground near her field, she found some grains of wheat. Excited, she thought to herself, If I plant these grains, I can grow wheat and make fresh roti for all of us!

Lal Pari called out to her friends, "Who will help me plant these grains of wheat?"

Gopu, munching on some grass, lazily replied, "Not I. I’m too tired."

Sundari, stretching under the shade of a tree, said, "Not I. I’m busy grooming my fur."

Bhola, lying in the mud to keep cool, yawned and said, "Not I. I need my rest."

Lal Pari sighed but didn’t give up. “Fine, I will do it myself,” she said. And so, she planted the wheat with care.

Weeks passed, and the wheat grew tall and golden under the warm sun. When it was time to harvest, Lal Pari once again asked, "Who will help me harvest the wheat?"

Gopu shook his head, "Not I. I have a headache."

Sundari lazily replied, "Not I. I’m napping right now."

Bhola grunted, "Not I. It’s too hot to work."

Lal Pari rolled her eyes and said, "Fine, I will do it myself." She harvested the wheat all on her own.

Next, the wheat needed to be ground into flour. Lal Pari asked, "Who will help me take the wheat to the mill to grind it into flour?"

Gopu, Sundari, and Bhola all gave excuses again. Frustrated but determined, Lal Pari said, "I’ll do it myself." She carried the heavy sack of wheat to the mill and brought back fresh flour.

Finally, it was time to make the dough and cook the roti. Lal Pari asked, "Who will help me knead the dough and cook the roti?"

Once again, Gopu, Sundari, and Bhola refused to help. “We’re too tired,” they said in unison.

So Lal Pari kneaded the dough, rolled it out, and cooked soft, warm, golden rotis all by herself. The delicious aroma of fresh roti filled the air, and her lazy friends suddenly appeared by her side.

"That smells so good!" said Gopu.

"We’re so hungry!" said Sundari.

"Please share the roti with us," said Bhola.

But Lal Pari shook her head. "When I asked for help, none of you were willing to do any work. Now that the roti is ready, I will eat it myself!" And with that, Lal Pari sat down and enjoyed her meal while her friends watched with regret.

From that day on, Gopu, Sundari, and Bhola realized the value of hard work and promised to help Lal Pari whenever she needed them.

Moral of the story: "You reap what you sow." Hard work and effort lead to rewards, while laziness brings regret. Always be willing to contribute your share of the work.

title: The Magic Pot
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in the quaint village of Dharmapur, there lived a poor but kind-hearted farmer named Ramu. He worked hard every day on his small plot of land, but the rocky soil yielded very little, and he struggled to make ends meet
content:
Once upon a time, in the quaint village of Dharmapur, there lived a poor but kind-hearted farmer named Ramu. He worked hard every day on his small plot of land, but the rocky soil yielded very little, and he struggled to make ends meet. Despite his hardships, Ramu always helped anyone in need, earning him the love and respect of the villagers.

One day, while digging in his field, Ramu struck something hard. Curious, he dug deeper and unearthed an old, large clay pot. It looked ancient, with intricate carvings on its surface. At first, Ramu thought, Maybe I can use this pot to store grains or water.

As he cleaned the pot, he absentmindedly placed his hoe inside it. To his astonishment, when he reached into the pot to retrieve the hoe, he found not one, but two identical hoes! Ramu was confused. How did this happen? he thought.

To test the pot again, he placed a mango inside it. Moments later, the pot produced not one, but two fresh mangoes. Realization dawned on Ramu—This is a magic pot! Whatever I place inside it doubles!

Excited, Ramu carried the pot home and began to use it wisely. He placed his last handful of rice inside the pot, and soon he had enough rice to fill all his storage containers. He did the same with wheat, lentils, and even money. Over time, Ramu's once-empty house became filled with food, supplies, and wealth.

But Ramu was not a greedy man. Instead of keeping everything for himself, he used the magic pot to help his fellow villagers. He doubled their seeds before the planting season, shared food with the hungry, and gave money to those in need. The villagers were amazed by Ramu’s generosity and blessed him for his kindness.

However, not everyone in the village was kind-hearted. A greedy merchant named Bhanu heard about the magic pot and decided to steal it. One night, Bhanu sneaked into Ramu’s house and took the pot while Ramu was asleep. Delighted with his theft, Bhanu hurried home and decided to test the pot by placing his gold coins inside.

As expected, the coins doubled. Bhanu was overjoyed. He became so excited that he wondered, What will happen if I put myself inside the pot? Maybe I can create another version of myself and become even more powerful!

Without thinking, Bhanu climbed into the pot. But instead of creating another version of him, the magic pot vanished with a loud pop, taking Bhanu with it. It was as if the pot refused to serve someone so selfish and greedy.

The next morning, when Ramu discovered the pot was missing, he was heartbroken. But when he heard what had happened to Bhanu, he understood that the magic pot had its own way of punishing greed. Though he missed the pot, Ramu continued to live happily, for he had enough wealth and the love of his villagers.

Moral of the story: "Greed leads to destruction, while generosity brings happiness." Be kind and share your blessings with others, for true wealth lies in helping those in need.

title: The Bear and the Two Friends
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled near a dense forest, there lived two friends named Sam and Leo. They were inseparable and did everything together
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled near a dense forest, there lived two friends named Sam and Leo. They were inseparable and did everything together. One day, they decided to venture into the forest to gather berries and explore. Before leaving, an old villager warned them, "The forest is beautiful but dangerous. Stay together, and be cautious."

As they wandered deeper into the forest, laughing and chatting, they suddenly heard a loud rustling in the bushes. Out of nowhere, a massive bear appeared, growling and charging toward them. Sam, who was quick on his feet, immediately climbed up a nearby tree to safety. Leo, however, was not as fast. He froze in fear, unsure of what to do.

Remembering a story he had once heard, Leo lay down on the ground and pretended to be dead. He held his breath and stayed perfectly still. The bear approached him, sniffed around his face, and after what felt like an eternity, it lumbered away, losing interest in what it thought was a lifeless body.

When the bear was finally out of sight, Sam climbed down from the tree and rushed over to Leo. "What did the bear say to you?" Sam asked, trying to lighten the mood. Leo, still shaken, looked at his friend and replied, "The bear told me to never trust a friend who abandons you in times of danger."

Sam's face turned red with shame. He realized that in his moment of fear, he had only thought of saving himself and left Leo to face the bear alone. He apologized sincerely, and Leo, being kind-hearted, forgave him. From that day on, Sam vowed to be a better friend and never leave Leo's side, no matter the danger.

Moral of the story: A true friend stands by you in times of trouble. Fair-weather friends may abandon you when you need them most, but a loyal friend will always have your back.

title: The Greedy Dog
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small village named Sonpur, there lived a stray dog called Moti. He was always on the lookout for food and never liked to share anything with others. His greed often got him into trouble, but he never learned his lesson
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village named Sonpur, there lived a stray dog called Moti. He was always on the lookout for food and never liked to share anything with others. His greed often got him into trouble, but he never learned his lesson.

One day, while wandering through the village, Moti found a juicy bone outside a butcher’s shop. His eyes sparkled with joy. What a delicious treat! he thought. Quickly, he grabbed the bone in his mouth and ran away before anyone could take it from him.

Moti decided to take the bone to a quiet place where he could enjoy it in peace. As he walked, he came across a narrow wooden bridge that stretched over a river. While crossing the bridge, he happened to look down and saw his reflection in the water.

Not realizing it was just his own image, Moti thought, Oh! There’s another dog in the water, and he has a bigger bone than mine! I must have that bone too!

Driven by greed, Moti growled at his reflection. But the dog in the water also seemed to growl back at him. Annoyed, Moti decided to scare the other dog away and take his bone. So, he opened his mouth to bark—and as soon as he did, his own bone fell into the river!

Moti watched in horror as the bone sank into the water and disappeared. He tried to reach for it, but it was too late. Now, he had nothing. Feeling foolish and sad, he walked away, realizing his own greed had cost him the delicious bone he already had.

From that day on, Moti learned to be satisfied with what he had and never to be greedy again.

Moral of the story: "Greed can make you lose what you already have." Be grateful for what you possess instead of always wanting more.

title: The Dog and the Bone
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small town named Rampur, there lived a hungry stray dog named Bhola. He roamed the streets in search of food every day
content:
Once upon a time, in a small town named Rampur, there lived a hungry stray dog named Bhola. He roamed the streets in search of food every day. One afternoon, after hours of searching, he finally found a delicious, meaty bone outside a butcher’s shop. Excited, he quickly grabbed it in his mouth and ran to a quiet place to enjoy his meal.

On his way, Bhola had to cross a small wooden bridge over a river. As he walked across, he happened to look down and saw his own reflection in the clear water below. But Bhola did not realize it was his own image. Instead, he thought there was another dog in the water holding a bigger, juicier bone.

That bone looks tastier than mine! Bhola thought greedily. If I can snatch it from that dog, I will have two bones instead of one!

Without thinking, Bhola opened his mouth to bark at the "other dog" in the water. But as soon as he did, his own bone slipped from his mouth and fell into the river with a splash. Bhola watched helplessly as his precious meal sank to the bottom and disappeared.

Now, he had nothing. His stomach growled, and he felt foolish for being so greedy. Sadly, Bhola walked away, learning an important lesson that day—greed can make you lose even what you already have.

Moral of the story: "Greed leads to loss." Be happy with what you have instead of always wanting more.

title: The Honest Woodcutter
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small village near a dense forest, there lived a poor but hardworking woodcutter named Harish. Every day, he would go into the forest, chop wood, and sell it in the market to earn a living
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village near a dense forest, there lived a poor but hardworking woodcutter named Harish. Every day, he would go into the forest, chop wood, and sell it in the market to earn a living. Though he had little, he was honest and content with what he earned.

One morning, Harish went to the forest as usual. He found a large, sturdy tree near a river and began chopping it down. As he swung his axe, his hands became sweaty, and suddenly, the axe slipped from his grip and fell into the deep river. Harish gasped in shock—his axe was his only means of livelihood!

Panicked, he tried to look into the river, but the water was too deep and fast-moving. He sat by the riverbank, feeling helpless and wondering how he would earn money without his axe. Unable to control his sorrow, he clasped his hands together and prayed, "Oh God, please help me! I have always been honest and hardworking. Without my axe, I will have nothing!"

Just then, the water of the river started shimmering, and from its depths, a divine figure emerged. It was the river goddess! She smiled kindly at Harish and said, "Do not worry, dear woodcutter. I will help you."

She dived into the river and returned holding a magnificent golden axe, encrusted with jewels. She showed it to Harish and asked, "Is this your axe?"

Harish was amazed by its beauty but shook his head and replied, "No, Goddess. This is not mine. My axe was made of simple iron."

The goddess smiled at his honesty and went back into the water. This time, she returned with a silver axe. "Is this your axe?" she asked.

Harish looked at it carefully and again shook his head. "No, Goddess. My axe was not made of silver either. It was just an ordinary iron axe."

The goddess nodded and disappeared into the river once more. Finally, she came back holding Harish’s simple iron axe. "Is this your axe?" she asked.

Harish’s face lit up with relief and happiness. "Yes! Yes! This is my axe! Thank you, Goddess!" he exclaimed with joy.

Pleased with his honesty, the goddess said, "You are a truthful and good man. As a reward for your honesty, I will give you all three axes—the iron, the silver, and the golden one."

Harish was overjoyed. He bowed respectfully to the goddess and thanked her sincerely. He took the axes and returned to his village, where he told everyone what had happened. The villagers were amazed and praised Harish for his honesty.

Soon, the story of the honest woodcutter spread far and wide. People admired him, and he continued to live a simple yet happy life, always staying true to his values.

Moral of the Story:
"Honesty is always rewarded." Truthfulness and integrity bring great rewards, while dishonesty leads to loss. Always be honest, even when no one is watching!

title: The Golden Goose
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small village near a dense forest, there lived a poor farmer named Ramu. He worked tirelessly on his small piece of land but barely earned enough to feed his family. Despite his struggles, Ramu was kind-hearted and never wished harm upon anyone.
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village near a dense forest, there lived a poor farmer named Ramu. He worked tirelessly on his small piece of land but barely earned enough to feed his family. Despite his struggles, Ramu was kind-hearted and never wished harm upon anyone.

One day, while working in his field, he found a shimmering golden egg lying in the nest of his old goose. His eyes widened in disbelief. “Could this be real?” he wondered. Carefully, he picked up the egg and took it home. When he showed it to a goldsmith in the village, the man confirmed that it was indeed pure gold.

Ramu was overjoyed. He sold the golden egg for a good price and used the money to buy food and other necessities for his family. The next morning, when he went to check on his goose, he was astonished to find another golden egg in its nest. Day after day, the goose laid a single golden egg, making Ramu and his family wealthier than ever.

With his newfound fortune, Ramu’s life changed completely. He no longer had to struggle for food or money. However, as time passed, greed started creeping into his heart. He thought, “Why should I wait for just one egg every day? What if I could get all the golden eggs at once?”

Blinded by greed, Ramu decided to kill the goose, believing that there must be a huge pile of golden eggs inside its belly. The next morning, he took a sharp knife and, without thinking twice, killed the innocent bird. But to his great shock and sorrow, when he cut open the goose, there were no golden eggs inside—only flesh and blood like any other bird.

Ramu fell to his knees, realizing the terrible mistake he had made. His greed had cost him dearly. If only he had been patient, the goose would have continued to give him golden eggs for a lifetime. But now, his source of wealth was gone forever.

With tears in his eyes, Ramu walked back home, filled with regret. From that day forward, he learned a valuable lesson: greed only leads to loss and suffering.

Moral of the Story:
"Greed leads to destruction." One should always be content and patient. Greed can make you lose even what you already have.

title: The Farmer and the Snake
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small village in India, there lived a kind-hearted farmer named Gopal. He was known for his generosity and willingness to help anyone in need.
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village in India, there lived a kind-hearted farmer named Gopal. He was known for his generosity and willingness to help anyone in need. He worked hard on his farm, and though he was not very rich, he was always content with what he had.

One winter morning, as Gopal was walking through his fields, he saw something unusual lying on the ground. As he moved closer, he realized it was a snake, frozen stiff due to the cold. The snake lay lifeless, barely breathing.

Gopal felt pity for the creature. “Poor thing! It must have been caught in the cold all night. If I don’t help it, it will surely die.”

Without thinking of the danger, Gopal carefully picked up the snake and tucked it inside his shawl to keep it warm. He carried it home and placed it near the fire, hoping it would regain its strength. After some time, the warmth of the fire revived the snake. It slowly opened its eyes and slithered around.

Just as Gopal was about to feel happy for saving the creature, the snake suddenly reared its head, hissed, and lunged at him, ready to strike!

Gopal quickly stepped back and grabbed a stick. “You ungrateful creature!” he shouted. “I saved your life, and now you want to bite me?”

The snake hissed and replied, “It is in my nature to bite, no matter how kind someone is to me.”

Realizing the danger, Gopal wasted no more time. He swung his stick and struck the snake, killing it instantly. He then sighed and said, “Kindness should be shown to those who deserve it, not to those who will repay it with harm.”

From that day on, Gopal became wiser. He continued to help others but was careful to recognize who truly deserved his kindness.

Moral of the Story:
"Never trust someone who is inherently wicked, no matter how kindly you treat them." Be kind, but also be wise in choosing whom to trust.

title: The Fisherman and His Wife
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small coastal village in India, there lived a poor fisherman named Ravi and his wife, Kamala. They lived in a tiny hut near the sea and survived on whatever fish Ravi could catch each day
content:
Once upon a time, in a small coastal village in India, there lived a poor fisherman named Ravi and his wife, Kamala. They lived in a tiny hut near the sea and survived on whatever fish Ravi could catch each day. Though they had little, Ravi was content with his life. However, Kamala was always dissatisfied and wanted more.

One day, while fishing in the ocean, Ravi caught a beautiful golden fish. To his surprise, the fish spoke in a gentle voice, "Please let me go, kind fisherman. I am no ordinary fish—I am a magical fish! If you spare my life, I will grant you any wish."

Ravi, being a kind man, did not desire anything for himself. He let the fish go, saying, "I need nothing, dear fish. Go and live freely in the ocean."

When Ravi returned home and told Kamala about the magical fish, she was furious. "How could you let such an opportunity go to waste?" she scolded. "Go back and ask the fish for a big house! I am tired of living in this small hut."

Ravi, though reluctant, returned to the sea and called out to the golden fish. The fish appeared and said, "What do you wish for, kind fisherman?"

With hesitation, Ravi replied, "My wife wishes for a big house."

"Go home, and you shall have it," said the fish, and with a splash, it disappeared.

When Ravi reached home, he was astonished to see that his tiny hut had transformed into a grand house. Kamala was overjoyed, but her greed only grew stronger.

The next day, she demanded, "Go back and ask for a palace! I want to be richer than anyone in the village."

Ravi, though unhappy, went back to the sea and made the wish. The magical fish granted it, and soon, Kamala was living in a magnificent palace. But even that was not enough.

“Now I want to be the queen! Tell the fish to make me the ruler of this land,” Kamala ordered.

Ravi hesitated but obeyed. This time, when he called the fish, the sky turned dark, and the sea became rough. The golden fish appeared, looking displeased.

"Go home, fisherman," it said, "for your wife’s greed has gone too far."

When Ravi returned, he found his grand palace had vanished, and in its place was the same small hut they had once lived in. Kamala wept bitterly, realizing that her endless greed had taken away everything. But it was too late.

From that day on, she learned to be content with what she had, and Ravi was happy to live simply once again.

Moral of the Story:
"Greed never leads to happiness; one should be content with what they have."

title: The Wind and The Sun
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time in a peaceful land in India, the Wind and the Sun were having a friendly argument. Each claimed to be stronger than the other.
content:
Once upon a time in a peaceful land in India, the Wind and the Sun were having a friendly argument. Each claimed to be stronger than the other.

The Wind blew hard and fast and said, “I am clearly the strongest. I can knock down trees, push boats across rivers, and fly kites into the sky!”

The Sun smiled gently and replied, “True strength doesn’t always come from force. Sometimes, a soft approach can be more powerful.”

To settle the debate, they spotted a traveler walking along a dusty road below, wearing a shawl wrapped tightly around him. The Wind said, “Let’s have a contest. Whoever can make the traveler remove his shawl will be declared the strongest.”

The Sun agreed.

The Wind went first. He blew with all his might. The trees swayed, the dust rose from the road, and the traveler’s shawl flapped wildly. But instead of removing the shawl, the traveler held onto it even tighter, wrapping it more securely around himself.

The Wind blew harder and harder, but the more he blew, the more the traveler clutched his shawl, shivering and uncomfortable.

Finally, the Wind gave up.

Then it was the Sun’s turn. He gently shone his warm rays down on the traveler. The air slowly became warm and pleasant. The traveler began to loosen his shawl. As the Sun continued to shine kindly, the traveler smiled, wiped the sweat from his forehead, and finally took off the shawl completely, carrying it on his arm.

The Wind was amazed.

The Sun simply said, “Kindness and warmth are sometimes more powerful than force and anger.”

Moral of the Story:
"Gentle kindness often achieves what force and fury cannot."

title: The Lion and the Mouse
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: In a vast jungle in India, there lived a mighty lion named Sheru. He was strong, feared by all, and considered the king of the forest
content:
In a vast jungle in India, there lived a mighty lion named Sheru. He was strong, feared by all, and considered the king of the forest. One afternoon, after a hearty meal, Sheru lay down beneath a shady tree and dozed off into a deep sleep.

While he was sleeping, a little mouse named Meenu, who lived nearby, came out of her hole to play. She ran up and down, squeaking with joy, and accidentally scurried across the lion’s huge paw. The sudden movement woke Sheru with a roar!

With a mighty swipe of his paw, he trapped the tiny mouse under it.
“Who dares disturb my sleep?” growled the lion.

Terrified, Meenu squeaked, “Oh mighty Sheru, please forgive me! I didn’t mean to wake you. I was just playing. Please let me go, and one day, I promise I’ll help you in return!”

Sheru laughed loudly. “You? Help me? How can such a tiny creature like you ever help a great lion like me?”

Still, the lion was amused by the mouse’s courage and decided to spare her life. “Go now, little one. But remember your promise.”

Days passed. One afternoon, while wandering near the edge of the jungle, Sheru got caught in a hunter’s net. He roared in anger and fear, thrashing and struggling, but the ropes were too strong.

Meenu, the little mouse, heard his cries. Without a second thought, she rushed to the spot.
“Don’t worry, Sheru. I haven’t forgotten my promise,” she said.

With her tiny teeth, she nibbled at the ropes of the net. Bit by bit, she gnawed through them until finally, the lion was free. Sheru was amazed and grateful.

“You were right, Meenu. Even the smallest friend can be the greatest help.”

From that day on, Sheru and Meenu became the best of friends, showing everyone in the jungle that size doesn’t matter when it comes to kindness and loyalty.

Moral of the Story:
"No act of kindness is ever wasted, and even the smallest friend can be the biggest help."

title: The Boy Who Cried Tiger
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a small village near the forests of South India, there lived a mischievous boy named Arjun. Every day, his parents sent him to take their goats to graze near the edge of the forest
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village near the forests of South India, there lived a mischievous boy named Arjun. Every day, his parents sent him to take their goats to graze near the edge of the forest. Arjun was a cheerful boy, but he often felt bored and lonely while watching the goats.

One afternoon, Arjun decided to have some fun. He ran toward the village shouting, “Tiger! Tiger! A tiger is chasing the goats!”

The villagers, alarmed and worried, grabbed sticks, sickles, and whatever they could find and ran to help him. But when they reached the forest clearing, there was no tiger in sight. Arjun burst into laughter and said, “I fooled you all! There was no tiger!”

The villagers were annoyed but let it go.

A few days later, Arjun played the same trick again. “Tiger! Tiger!” he screamed. The villagers rushed once more—only to find Arjun laughing again.

“You’re so easy to fool!” he said.

This time, the villagers were angry. “Don’t cry ‘tiger’ when there isn’t one. What if we don’t believe you next time?”

But Arjun just laughed and didn’t take their words seriously.

Then one day, while Arjun was watching the goats, a real tiger came out of the forest! It growled and began chasing the goats. Frightened, Arjun ran toward the village shouting, “Tiger! Tiger! Please help! This time it’s real!”

But no one came. The villagers thought he was joking again.

Arjun screamed and cried, but no one believed him. By the time some villagers came to check, the goats had scattered, and the tiger had vanished back into the forest.

Arjun sat on the ground, ashamed and sad. He realized that his lies had caused him to lose the trust of the villagers.

From that day onward, Arjun never lied again. He became honest and responsible, earning back the trust of the people slowly.

Moral of the Story: “If you lie all the time, no one will believe you even when you tell the truth.”

title: The Ugly Duckling
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: In a quiet village pond in India, surrounded by lotus flowers and chirping birds, lived a mother duck named Kaveri. One fine morning, she sat on her nest, waiting for her eggs to hatch
content:
In a quiet village pond in India, surrounded by lotus flowers and chirping birds, lived a mother duck named Kaveri. One fine morning, she sat on her nest, waiting for her eggs to hatch. One by one, the eggs cracked open, and out came six fluffy little ducklings. But the last egg, which was larger than the rest, took a little longer.

When it finally hatched, out came a duckling that looked quite different. He was bigger, with grey feathers instead of yellow. His beak was slightly longer, and he walked awkwardly. The other ducklings stared.

“What an odd-looking duckling!” they whispered.

Even the farm animals laughed at him. The chicks called him “ugly,” and the goats giggled when he walked by. The poor duckling, whose name was Neel, felt sad and unwanted. His own brothers and sisters didn’t want to play with him.

Unable to bear the teasing, Neel ran away from the pond and wandered through forests, fields, and rivers. Everywhere he went, the animals rejected him for looking different.

One day, as winter came, Neel found shelter by a lake, shivering and lonely. But he survived. Months passed. When spring arrived, the air turned warm, and the trees blossomed.

One morning, Neel saw his reflection in the water—and to his surprise, he wasn’t an awkward, grey duckling anymore. He had grown into a beautiful white swan, with long, graceful wings and a shining neck.

Just then, a group of swans glided across the lake. They saw Neel and called out, “Come join us!”

Neel hesitated. “But I’m not like you…”

One of the swans smiled and said, “You are one of us. You were always a swan—you just didn’t know it yet.”

Neel joined them, spreading his wings proudly. As he soared across the blue sky with his new friends, he realized he had never been ugly—he was just different, and it had taken time for his beauty to shine.

Moral of the Story:
"Don’t judge yourself by how others treat you. True beauty and worth come from within, and everyone blossoms in their own time."

title: Snow White
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: True beauty lies in kindness and honesty. Even in hard times, goodness always finds a way to shine
content:
Once upon a time, in a peaceful kingdom in the hills of Himachal Pradesh, there lived a kind and gentle queen. One day, as she sat by her window, sewing by the snow, she pricked her finger. As she looked at the drop of blood on the white snow, she whispered, “I wish for a daughter with skin as fair as snow, lips as red as a rose, and hair as black as the night.”

Not long after, the queen had a beautiful baby girl just like she had wished. She named her Snow White. But sadly, the queen fell ill and passed away. The king remarried, and the new queen was beautiful but very proud and cruel.

This new queen had a magical mirror. Every day, she would ask,
“Mirror, mirror on the wall,
Who is the fairest of them all?”

The mirror always replied, “You are, O Queen.”
But one day, the mirror answered, “Snow White is the fairest of them all.”

Jealous and furious, the queen ordered a soldier to take Snow White deep into the forest and leave her there. But the kind soldier couldn’t harm her. He let her go and told her to run far away.

Snow White wandered through the thick forest, frightened and tired, until she came upon a tiny cottage. Inside, everything was small—little chairs, tiny bowls, and beds. She cleaned the cottage and fell asleep in one of the beds.

The cottage belonged to seven little dwarfs who worked in the nearby hills digging for gems. When they came home and found Snow White, they were surprised, but also happy to have her. She told them her story, and they promised to keep her safe.

But the wicked queen soon found out Snow White was still alive. Disguising herself as an old woman, she went to the cottage and gave Snow White a poisoned apple. With one bite, Snow White fell into a deep, magic sleep.

The dwarfs were heartbroken. They placed her gently in a glass coffin in the forest. One day, a kind prince, who had heard tales of Snow White’s beauty and kindness, came to see her. When he gently lifted her, the piece of poisoned apple fell from her mouth—and she opened her eyes!

Snow White was awake! The prince and the dwarfs were overjoyed. Snow White smiled and thanked them all for their love. The prince asked her to come with him to his palace, and Snow White agreed.

They were married with great celebration, and Snow White lived happily ever after in peace and joy, always remembering her little friends in the forest.

Moral of the Story:
“True beauty lies in kindness and honesty. Even in hard times, goodness always finds a way to shine.”

title: Cinderella
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, in a faraway land, there lived a sweet and gentle girl named Cinderella. She was kind to everyone, whether it was people, animals, or even the tiniest bird in the garden
content:
Once upon a time, in a faraway land, there lived a sweet and gentle girl named Cinderella. She was kind to everyone, whether it was people, animals, or even the tiniest bird in the garden. Sadly, her life was not easy. After her mother passed away, her father remarried, and Cinderella gained a stepmother and two stepsisters.

The stepmother was proud and cruel, and her daughters were selfish and unkind. They made Cinderella do all the housework—sweeping, scrubbing, cooking, and mending. While they wore fine dresses and went to parties, poor Cinderella had to wear old clothes and sleep near the fireplace, which left her covered in ashes. That is how she got her name—Cinderella.

One day, an announcement came from the king’s palace. The prince was holding a grand ball, and every young maiden in the kingdom was invited. The stepmother and stepsisters were excited. They dressed in their best gowns and left for the ball, laughing at Cinderella when she wished to go.

After they left, Cinderella sat alone by the fire and began to cry. Suddenly, a gentle light filled the room, and her fairy godmother appeared! With a wave of her magic wand, she turned Cinderella’s ragged dress into a sparkling gown and her old shoes into shining glass slippers. A pumpkin became a golden carriage, and mice turned into horses.

“Go to the ball, my dear,” said the fairy godmother, “but remember—you must return before midnight, for the magic will end.”

Cinderella thanked her and went to the ball. When she entered the palace, everyone stopped to admire her beauty. The prince himself was enchanted. He danced only with Cinderella, forgetting all others.

As the clock neared midnight, Cinderella remembered her fairy godmother’s warning. She quickly ran out of the palace, leaving behind one of her glass slippers on the staircase.

The prince was determined to find her. The next day, he sent his servants across the kingdom with the slipper. Every maiden tried it on, but it fit no one. At last, they came to Cinderella’s home. Her stepsisters tried to squeeze their feet into the slipper, but it was no use.

When Cinderella shyly asked to try, her stepmother laughed. But the slipper slid on her foot perfectly! At that very moment, her fairy godmother’s magic shimmered, and Cinderella appeared in her beautiful gown. The prince knew she was the one.

He married Cinderella, and they lived happily ever after. The kind and gentle girl who once sat by the fireplace became a princess, loved by all.

Moral of the Story:
“Kindness, patience, and hope can turn even the darkest days into the brightest happily-ever-after.”

title: The Three Little Pigs
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, there were three little pigs who lived with their mother. One day, their mother said, “My dear children, you are grown now.
content:
Once upon a time, there were three little pigs who lived with their mother. One day, their mother said, “My dear children, you are grown now. Go out into the world and build homes of your own. But remember—whatever you do, do it well.”

So the three little pigs set off on their journey.

The first little pig was in a hurry. He wanted to play and have fun, so he built his house quickly with straw. It was light and easy to stack, and soon he was finished. “Now I can play all day!” he said happily.

The second little pig worked a little harder. He built his house with sticks. It took longer than straw, but it was stronger. “This will do just fine,” he said, proud of his work.

The third little pig was wise and patient. He wanted his house to be safe and strong. So he built it carefully with bricks. It took much time and effort, but at last, he had a sturdy home.

Not long after, a big bad wolf came along. He was hungry and saw the first little pig’s straw house.

“Little pig, little pig, let me come in!” the wolf growled.
“Not by the hair of my chinny-chin-chin!” squeaked the little pig.

“Then I’ll huff, and I’ll puff, and I’ll blow your house in!” roared the wolf. And with one big blow—whoosh!—the straw house flew apart. The first little pig ran as fast as he could to his brother’s stick house.

The wolf followed and knocked on the door.
“Little pigs, little pigs, let me come in!”
“Not by the hair of our chinny-chin-chins!” they replied.

“Then I’ll huff, and I’ll puff, and I’ll blow your house in!” The wolf blew with all his might, and CRASH!—the stick house tumbled down. The two pigs squealed and ran to their brother’s brick house.

The wolf came after them and banged on the door.
“Little pigs, little pigs, let me come in!”
“Not by the hair of our chinny-chin-chins!” answered the three pigs together.

“Then I’ll huff, and I’ll puff, and I’ll blow your house in!” The wolf huffed, and he puffed, and he blew with all his strength—but the brick house stood firm. Again and again, he tried, but the strong brick walls would not fall.

At last, the tired wolf gave up. “I’ll find my dinner somewhere else!” he grumbled, and he ran off into the forest, never to bother the pigs again.

The three little pigs danced with joy. They hugged their clever brother and said, “Your hard work saved us all!” From that day, they lived happily and safely in the sturdy brick house.

Moral of the Story:
“Hard work and patience always pay off, while laziness can bring trouble.”

title: The Goose That Laid the Golden Eggs
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Greed can destroy the good things we already have. Be patient and grateful
content:
Once upon a time, in a small village, there lived a poor farmer and his wife. They worked very hard every day but still found it difficult to earn enough to live comfortably. One morning, while feeding their animals, the farmer discovered something unusual in the nest of his goose.

To his surprise, the goose had laid a shiny golden egg! At first, he thought it must be a trick, but when he picked it up, he realized it was truly made of gold. Overjoyed, he ran to his wife and said, “Look! Our goose has given us a golden egg. We will never be poor again!”

Every day after that, the goose laid one golden egg. Slowly, the farmer and his wife became rich. They bought a bigger house, new clothes, and had plenty of food. The farmer should have been satisfied and grateful—but greed began to grow in his heart.

One day, the wife said, “If the goose lays a golden egg every day, then surely there must be many golden eggs inside her. Why should we wait day by day? Let’s cut her open and take them all at once!”

The farmer hesitated, but his greed overcame his sense. He thought, If we have all the gold now, we will be the richest people in the land. So, the foolish farmer killed the goose. But when he opened it, there were no golden eggs inside—only an ordinary goose like any other.

The farmer and his wife were heartbroken. Their source of wealth was gone forever. Instead of being the richest people, they had lost everything because of their greed.

From that day, the farmer learned a painful lesson—those who want too much, too quickly, often lose everything in the end.

Moral of the Story:
“Greed can destroy the good things we already have. Be patient and grateful.”

title: The Pig and the Sheep
author: Karthik Kumar D K
summary: Once upon a time, on a quiet little farm, there lived a pig and a sheep. They both stayed in the same barnyard, but they were very different in their ways
content:
My dear children, let me tell you a story from long, long ago. It carries a lesson that life has taught me, and I want you to remember it as you grow.

There was once a small village where a kind farmer lived. In his barnyard, he kept many animals—among them were a pig and a sheep. Now, though they lived close together, the two were very different in nature.

The pig was restless and loud. If anything displeased him, he would grunt and squeal until the whole farm heard him. The sheep, on the other hand, was gentle and quiet. She never complained, even when the farmer came to shear off her wool. She trusted that what was taken would grow back again.

One hot summer morning, the farmer caught hold of the pig and tied a rope around its leg. He was taking it to the market. The moment the pig felt the rope, it cried out in a terrible voice—screeching, squealing, and fighting with all its might.

“Why me? Why me?” it screamed. “Why don’t you take the sheep instead? You cut her wool off so many times, and yet she never makes a sound. Why am I always the one who suffers?”

The farmer said nothing, but the sheep, who had been watching quietly, lifted her head and spoke softly, “Brother Pig, you must understand—when the farmer takes my wool, it does not harm me. I feel no real pain, and my wool grows back again. But when he takes you away, it is not your wool he wants—it is your life. That is why your cries are loud, for you know the truth in your heart.”

The pig fell silent. In that moment, it realized the sheep had always carried her burden with patience, while it had spent its days grumbling about smaller troubles.

Now, my dear ones, this is what life teaches us: everyone carries their own burden, but not all burdens are the same. Some may look easy from the outside, but you do not know how heavy they are until you carry them yourself. Do not compare your troubles with others, and do not laugh at someone else’s pain. Instead, face your own struggles with courage and patience, just as the sheep did.

Moral of the Story:
“Each one knows the weight of their own burden. Do not judge, do not complain—learn to bear your share with patience and wisdom.”
